data.title: Famous Birthdays on March 10
data.meta_description: Famous birthdays for the 10th of March. See which celebrities, historical figures, scientists and criminals were born on March 10.
data.text:
Birthdays 1 - 200 of 262

Vasili II 'the Blind' Grand Prince of Moscow (1425-62) (d. 1462)

Ferdinand II of Aragon

King of Aragon (1479-1516), King of Naples (1504-16), born in Sada Palace, Sos, Aragon

Ferdinand I, Holy Roman Emperor (1558-64) who organized defense against the Ottoman invasion, born in Alcalá de Henares, Castile (d. 1564)

Akechi Mitsuhide

Japanese samurai who assassinated daimyō Oda Nobunaga, born in Tara Castle, Mino Province, Japan

Thomas Howard, English 4th Duke of Norfolk (executed for treason by Queen Elizabeth I for his part in Ridolfi plot to overthrow her), born in Kenninghall, Norfolk, England (d. 1572)

Constantine Huygens Jr., Dutch poet, painter and cartoonist, born in The Hague, Dutch Republic (d. 1697)

1628 Marcello Malpighi, Italian physician who founded the science of microscopic anatomy, born in Crevalcore, near Bologna, Papal States (d. 1694)

Adolf H. van Rechteren, Dutch diplomat and politician (d. 1731)

Gaetano Maria Schiassi, Italian violinist and composer (Christmas Symphony), born in Bologna, Papal States (d. 1754)

Georg Steller, German naturalist (d. 1746)

Christian Friedrich Schale, German organist, harpsichordist, and composer, born in Brandenburg, Kingdom of Prussia (d. 1800)

1713 Raphael Weiss, German composer and priest, born in Wangen (d. 1779)

John Gunby, Maryland Soldier in the American Revolutionary War (d. 1807)

John Playfair, Scottish clergyman, geologist and mathematician, born in Benvie, Scotland (d. 1819)

Lorenzo Da Ponte [Emanuele Conegliano], Italian-American librettist (Don Giovanni), poet, and libertine priest, born in Ceneda, Republic of Venice (now Vittorio Veneto, Italy) (d. 1838)

Philipp Christoph Kayser, German composer and pianist, born in Frankfurt (d. 1823)

Joseph Williamson, English philanthropist and tunnel builder (Williamson tunnels in Liverpool), born in West Riding, England (d. 1840)

Georg Friedrich Creuzer, German classical scholar (Idea und Probe), born in Marburg an der Lahn, Hesse (d. 1858)

Friedrich von Schlegel, German romantic writer and critic (Lucinde), born in Hanover (d. 1829)

Louise, Queen of Prussia, wife of Frederick William III (famously pleaded with Napoleon), born in Hanover (d. 1810)

Juan José Landaeta, Venezuelan composer, born in Caracas, Venezuela, (d. 1814)

William Etty, English painter of historical nudes, born in York, England (d. 1849)

Joseph Freiherr von Eichendorff, German Romantic poet (Das Marmorbild), born at Schloß Lubowitz, Prussia (d. 1857)

José María Vargas, Venezuelan doctor, botanist and 2nd President of Venezuela (1835-36), born in La Guaira, Venezuela (d. 1854)

William David Porter, Commander (Union Navy), (d. 1864)

John McCloskey, 1st American cardinal and Archbishop of New York, born in Brooklyn, New York (d. 1885)

1810 Samuel Ferguson, Irish poet (d. 1886)

Victor Tesch, Belgian industrialist and politician, born in Messancy, Belgium (d. 1892)

George Wythe Randolph, American Secretary of War for the Confederacy, born in Charlottesville, Virginia (d. 1867)

Willem Roelofs, Dutch painter and lithographer, born in Amsterdam (d. 1897)

Thomas James Churchill, Major General (Confederate Army), (d. 1905)

William Henry Penrose, American Brigadier General (Union Army), born at Madison Barracks in Sackett's Harbor, New York (d. 1903)

Dudley Buck, American organist, composer, and music writer, born in Hartford, Connecticut (d. 1909)

Ina Coolbrith, American poet laureate of California (1st poet laureate of any US state), born in Nauvoo, Illinois (d. 1928)

Pablo de Sarasate, Spanish violinist and composer (Spanish Dancer), born in Pamplona, Spain (d. 1908)

Edward Baker Lincoln, son of U.S. President Abraham Lincoln (d. 1850)

Kate Sheppard

New Zealand suffragette and the most prominent member of New Zealand's women's suffrage movement, born in Liverpool, England

Mary Mills Patrick, American author and 1st President of Istanbul Woman's College, born in Canterbury, New Hampshire (d. 1940)

1850 Spencer Gore, British tennis player (1st Wimbledon winner 1877), born in Wimbledon, England (d. 1906)

Pauline Johnson

Canadian poet, writer and performer (The White Wampum), born on The Native Reserve, Upper Canada [1]

E J Ratcliffe [Edward], British stage and screen actor, born in London (d. 1948)

Pim Mulier, Dutch sports organizer, founded the Dutch Football and Athletics Association, Koninklijke HFC, established hockey in the Netherlands and President of the International Skating Union (1892-94), born in Witmarsum, Netherlands (d. 1954)

Amanda Aldridge, British opera singer, pianist, teacher, and composer of parlour songs and light orchestral pieces music, born in Upper Norwood, London, England (d. 1956)

Hector Guimard, French Art Nouveau architect and designer (entrances to Paris Metros), born in Lyon (d. 1942)

Lillian Wald

American pioneering nurse and social activist who started American community nursing with the Henry Street Settlement in NYC, born in Cincinnati, Ohio

Alfred Kastner, Austrian-American harpist and composer, born in Vienna, Austria (d. 1948)

Felix Borowski, British-American composer, educator (Chicago Musical College, 1896-1925), and musicologist (Chicago Symphony, 1908-56), born in Burton-in-Kendal, England (d. 1956)

Jakob Wassermann, German writer and novelist (My Life as German and Jew), born in Fürth, Bavaria, German Empire (d. 1934)

Alexander Borisovich Goldenweiser, Russian pianist, and composer (Contrapuntal Sketches), born in Kishinev, Russia (d. 1961)

Edvard Eriksen, Danish-Icelandic sculptor, born in Copenhagen, Denmark (d. 1959)

Karel van de Woestijne, Flemish writer and poet (God at Sea), born in Ghent, Belgium (d. 1929)

German politician and German Chancellor (1925-26), born in Berlin, German Empire

Swiss composer (King David; Pacific 231), born in Le Havre, France

Eva Turner, British operatic soprano, born in Werneth, Oldham, England (d. 1990)

Warner Anderson, American actor (The Bubble, Destination Moon, Peyton Place), born in Brooklyn, New York (d. 1976)

Frank Perconte, American sergeant from Easy Company during WWII (portrayed in Band of Brothers), born in Joliet, Illinois (d. 2013)

Günther Rall, German ace fighter pilot, born in Gaggenau, Germany (d. 2009)

1918 Heywood Hale Broun, American TV commentator and sports correspondent, born in New York City (d. 2001)

Marion Hutton [Thornburg], American singer (Glenn Miller Orchestra, 1938-42), and actress (In Society), born in Battle Creek, Michigan (d. 1987) [1]

(Kenneth) "Jethro" Burns, American country singer, and mandolin player (Homer & Jethro -"The Battle of Kookamonga"), born in Conasauga, Tennessee (d. 1989)

(John) Don Abney, American session and touring jazz pianist, and musical director, born in Baltimore, Maryland (d. 2000)

Ed van der Elsken, Dutch photographer (Een liefdesgeschiedenis), born in Amsterdam, Netherlands (d. 1900)

1925 Manolis Anagnostakis, Greek poet (d. 2005)

Barbara Sinatra, American model and philanthropist, born in Bosworth, Missouri (d. 2017)

1927 Donn Trenner, American jazz pianist, arranger, and orchestra leader (Steve Allen's Westinghouse Show), born in New Haven, Connecticut (d. 2020)

Arthur Milton, English footballer (Arsenal, 1951-55) and cricketer (opening batsman, 2 tests - 1958, 1959), born in Bedmister, Bristol, England (d .2007)

American assassin of Martin Luther King Jr., born in Alton, Illinois

Fou Ts'ong, Chinese-British concert pianist, born in Shanghai, Republic of China (d. 2020)

(Graham) "Polly" Farmer, Australian rules footballer. 1953-71 (East Perth, Geelong, West Perth), born in North Fremantle, Australia (d. 2019)

American martial arts actor (Missing in Action), born in Ryan, Oklahoma
